user.name: Microsoft
user.bio: Open source projects and samples from Microsoft

issue.title: Simplify ffplay input handling in Makefile
issue.body: Let ffplay read from file directly instead of pipe.

comment.body:
This breaks my "SeymourDuncan" test case, which is just "repeat over some random mp3 samples of guitar pickups by Seymour Duncan".

That's not a great test-case, but I don't have any actual reasonable guitar samples I can use (my own guitar only makes horrible screeching noises - not the fault of the guitar).  But it is one of the very very few actual real audio test cases I have, so I don't want to break it.

issue.title: Phaser filter instability when pot3 > 0.5
issue.body:
## Summary

The phaser effect becomes unstable (produces NaN/silence) when `pot3` exceeds approximately 0.5.

## Root Cause

In `phaser.h`, the `phaser_init()` function doubles `pot3` before cubing it:

```c
pot3 = 2*pot3;
phaser.center_f = linear(pot3*pot3*pot3, 50, 880);  // Comment says "50Hz .. 1kHz"
```

When `pot3 = 1.0`:
- After doubling: `pot3 = 2.0`
- After cubing: `pot3³ = 8.0`
- `center_f = 50 + 8 × (880 - 50) = 6690 Hz`

Then in `phaser_step()`:
```c
float freq = fastpow(2, lfo*phaser.octaves) * phaser.center_f;
```

With `octaves = 4` and LFO at maximum (+1):
- `freq = 2⁴ × 6690 = 107,040 Hz`

This far exceeds the Nyquist frequency (24kHz at 48kHz sample rate), causing the biquad allpass filter to become unstable and produce NaN values.

## Suggested Fix

Option A: Remove the doubling (simplest):
```c
// pot3 = 2*pot3;  // Remove this line
phaser.center_f = linear(pot3*pot3*pot3, 50, 880);
```

Option B: Clamp frequency in `phaser_step()`:
```c
float freq = fastpow(2, lfo*phaser.octaves) * phaser.center_f;
freq = fminf(freq, SAMPLES_PER_SEC * 0.45f);  // Stay below Nyquist
```

## Reproduction

1. Set phaser effect
2. Turn pot3 to maximum (1.0)
3. Audio output becomes silent (NaN propagation)

## Environment

Discovered while porting AudioNoise to WebAssembly (48kHz sample rate).

Demo: https://akihiko.shirai.as/bad-apple-html/
Source: https://github.com/kaitas/bad-apple-html
Video: https://youtu.be/_5ruHnVR9sI

Thanks for the elegant DSP code! The single-header design made this port straightforward.

issue.title: Phaser filter instability when pot3 > 0.5
issue.body:
## Summary

The phaser effect becomes unstable (produces NaN/silence) when `pot3` exceeds approximately 0.5.

## Root Cause

In `phaser.h`, the `phaser_init()` function doubles `pot3` before cubing it:

```c
pot3 = 2*pot3;
phaser.center_f = linear(pot3*pot3*pot3, 50, 880);  // Comment says "50Hz .. 1kHz"
```

When `pot3 = 1.0`:
- After doubling: `pot3 = 2.0`
- After cubing: `pot3³ = 8.0`
- `center_f = 50 + 8 × (880 - 50) = 6690 Hz`

Then in `phaser_step()`:
```c
float freq = fastpow(2, lfo*phaser.octaves) * phaser.center_f;
```

- `freq = 2⁴ × 6690 = 107,040 Hz`

This far exceeds the Nyquist frequency (24kHz at 48kHz sample rate), causing the biquad allpass filter to become unstable and produce NaN values.

## Suggested Fix

Option A: Remove the doubling (simplest):
```c
// pot3 = 2*pot3;  // Remove this line
phaser.center_f = linear(pot3*pot3*pot3, 50, 880);
```

Option B: Clamp frequency in `phaser_step()`:
```c
float freq = fastpow(2, lfo*phaser.octaves) * phaser.center_f;
freq = fminf(freq, SAMPLES_PER_SEC * 0.45f);  // Stay below Nyquist
```

## Reproduction

1. Set phaser effect
2. Turn pot3 to maximum (1.0)
3. Audio output becomes silent (NaN propagation)

## Environment

Discovered while porting AudioNoise to WebAssembly (48kHz sample rate).

Demo: https://akihiko.shirai.as/bad-apple-html/
Source: https://github.com/kaitas/bad-apple-html

Thanks for the elegant DSP code! The single-header design made this port straightforward.

comment.body:
You are of course correct. A lot of the pots are very random ranges, but this one in particular more random than some.

I think I was messing with it in order to get a much clearer response with the test file while on a noisy plane with not-so-great in-ear headphones, and that's when I changed the "octaves" to be a larger range for some extreme frequency range.

And that worked fine with the default pot setting (in the middle), but yeah, it makes the higher frequencies go way past the range. You can see that the comment about the center frequency is completely wrong because I've been randomly messing with this all.

I think I want to keep the default center frequency somewhere in roughly that 880Hz range (no good reason for it), but I'll change 'octaves' back to 2 (four octaves both ways is really excessive and part of the problem), and also just make the cubic pot behavior be quadratic. 

Thanks for noticing.

issue.title: Question about 52kHz sample rate vs standard 48kHz efficiency
issue.body: I read that the GuitarPedal hardware uses 52kHz for no apparent reason. Do you think this significantly impacts the performance of effects processing like the Phaser or Flanger in terms of latency, or does RightThing(tm) handle it without any extra cost?

comment.body:
The guitar pedal hardware does that 52k sample rate simply because that way it has a integer multiplier from the system clock (150MHz) to the i2s PIO engine that runs at twice the i2s BCLK.

(In fact, the sample rate is 52083.33333.. it's the 150MHz system clock, divided down by 30 to give a 5MHz PIO clock, which runs at twice the BCLK speed of 2.5MHz, and then divide that with 48 - for with two 24-bit cycles per sample - you end up with a 52kHz sample rate)

The RP2354A can do fractional PIO engine frequency multipliers, but I *assume* that it is always at system clock boundaries, so I picked an integer multiplier to avoid jitter on the i2s lines.  The TAC5112 - which is the CODEC chip I use on that board - will lock onto the clock signal automatically, and has no precision crystal of its own, and I simply wanted to avoid any jitter issues.

If somebody knows better about how the fractional PIO cycle divider works, holler.

Anyway, the difference between 48kHz and 52kHz is not meaningful, and the software does take that into account when doing frequency filtering etc, so it should not be something you can actually hear in any way.
